<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/53  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 410, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes

You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 710, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates springs made of metal wire, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 98, 798, 316]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 920, 396]]<|/det|>
The student constructs several springs from wire of thickness \(t\). Each spring has a different cross-sectional area \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 653, 427]]<|/det|>
The student investigates how the spring constant \(k\) varies with \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 439, 571, 458]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(k\) and \(A\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 464, 536, 500]]<|/det|>
\[k = \frac{\beta\rho t^4}{A^{\frac{3}{2}}N}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 507, 920, 542]]<|/det|>
where \(\rho\) is the density of the metal, \(N\) is the number of turns of wire on the spring and \(\beta\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 555, 712, 573]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(k\) and \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 663, 588]]<|/det|>
Explain how your results could be used to determine a value for \(\beta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 600, 816, 635]]<|/det|>
You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 648, 395, 666]]<|/det|>
● the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 677, 410, 695]]<|/det|>
● the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 706, 348, 724]]<|/det|>
● the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 736, 351, 753]]<|/det|>
● the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 765, 447, 782]]<|/det|>
● any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the discharge of a capacitor through a resistor using the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 116, 670, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 338, 532, 356]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 369, 920, 419]]<|/det|>
The student initially closes the switch and charges the capacitor. The switch is then opened and a stop-watch is started. The capacitor discharges through the resistor. At time \(t\) the potential difference \(V\) across the capacitor is measured.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 431, 567, 450]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(V\) and \(t\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 452, 566, 486]]<|/det|>
\[V = \left(\frac{Q_0}{C}\right)\mathrm{e}^{-\left(\frac{t}{RC}\right)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 492, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
where \(Q_0\) is the charge of the fully charged capacitor, \(C\) is the capacitance of the capacitor and \(R\) is the resistance of the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 146, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 540, 658, 559]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of In V on the \(y\)-axis against \(t\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 570, 611, 588]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 744, 917, 762]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 775, 917, 793]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 791, 920, 809]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 485, 89]]<|/det|> Values of \(t\) and \(V\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 539, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 129, 789, 380]]<|/det|>
\(t/\mathrm {s}\)\(V/V\)\(\ln \left(V/V\right)\)
06.2 ± 0.2
64.6 ± 0.2
123.4 ± 0.2
182.6 ± 0.2
242.0 ± 0.2
301.4 ± 0.2
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 584, 413]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(\ln\) (V/V) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 532, 428]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \(\ln\) (V/V). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 411, 920, 429]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 443, 144, 462]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 443, 180, 462]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 443, 489, 462]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\ln\) (V/V) against \(t/\mathrm {s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 459, 445, 477]]<|/det|> Include error bars for \(\ln\) (V/V). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 488, 178, 507]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 488, 920, 522]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Both lines should be clearly labelled. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 536, 180, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 536, 920, 570]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 797, 920, 816]]<|/det|>
gradient = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Do **not** include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 231, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 262, 146, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 262, 181, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 262, 920, 295]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to **(a)**, **(c)(iii)** and **(c)(iv)**, determine values of \(C\) and \(Q_0\). Include appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 308, 329, 325]]<|/det|>
Data: \(R = 39 \text{k}\Omega\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 415, 917, 435]]<|/det|>
<form>C = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 448, 917, 467]]<|/det|>
<form>Q_0 = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 463, 920, 482]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 494, 181, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 618, 512]]<|/det|>
The percentage uncertainty in the value of \(R\) is \(5\%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 524, 529, 543]]<|/det|>
Determine the absolute uncertainty in \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 664, 920, 683]]<|/det|>
<form>absolute uncertainty in \(C =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 696, 146, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 695, 764, 714]]<|/det|>
Using your results, determine the value of \(V\) when the time \(t\) is 1.0 minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 850, 920, 868]]<|/det|>
<form>V = .................................................... V [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 876, 920, 894]]<|/det|>
